[[Bill Koch (businessman)|Bill Koch]] (twin brother) | networth = [[US$]]50.2 billion (June 2018) }} '''David Hamilton Koch''' ({{IPAc-en|k|oʊ|k}}; born May 3, 1940) is an American businessman, philanthropist, political activist, and chemical engineer. He joined the family business [[Koch Industries]], the second-largest privately held company in the United States, in 1970. He became president of the subsidiary Koch Engineering in 1979, and became a co-owner of Koch Industries, with older brother [[Charles G. Koch|Charles]], in 1983, and served as an executive vice president until his retirement in 2018.[http://www.theadvocates.org/celebrities/david-koch.html] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070226111813/http://www.theadvocates.org/celebrities/david-koch.html|date=February 26, 2007}} Upon retirement in June 2018 due to health issues, Koch received the title of Director Emeritus. Koch is an influential [[Libertarianism in the United States|libertarian]]. He was the 1980 candidate for [[Vice President of the United States]] from the [[United States Libertarian Party]] and helped finance the campaign. He founded [[Citizens for a Sound Economy]].Suzan Mazur, [https://books.google.com/books?id=wk2FfQQ_DmsC&lpg=PA244&dq=David%20H.%20Koch&pg=PA244#v=onepage&q=David%20H.%20Koch&f=false "The Altenberg 16: An Exposé of the Evolution Industry"], ''North Atlantic Books'', 2010, 343 pages He and his brother Charles have donated to political advocacy groups and to political campaigns, almost entirely [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]].{{cite web|url=https://www.opensecrets.org/orgs/summary.php?id=D000000186&cycle=A |title=Koch Industries: Summary |publisher=OpenSecrets.org |accessdate=June 10, 2015}} As of June 2018, he was ranked as the 12th-richest person in the world, (tied with his brother Charles), with a fortune of $50.7 billion.{{cite web |url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/david-koch/|title=David Koch|accessdate=June 5, 2018}} ''[[Portfolio.com|Condé Nast Portfolio]]'' described him as "one of the most generous but low-key philanthropists in America".Weiss, Gary, [http://www.portfolio.com/executives/features/2008/10/15/Profile-of-Billionaire-David-Koch/ "The Price of Immortality"], ''[[Portfolio.com|Condé Nast Portfolio]]'', November 2008. Koch has contributed to several charities including [[Lincoln Center]], [[Sloan Kettering]], [[New York-Presbyterian Hospital]] and the Dinosaur Wing at the [[American Museum of Natural History]]. The New York State Theater at Lincoln Center, home of the [[New York City Ballet]], was renamed the [[David H. Koch Theater]] in 2008 following a gift of $100 million for the renovation of the theater. Koch was the fourth richest person in the USA as of 2012, and the wealthiest resident of [[New York City]] as of 2013.{{cite news |agency=Forbes|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/david-koch|title=David Koch – Forbes|date=March 9, 2011|accessdate=June 10, 2015}} He is a survivor of the [[USAir Flight 1493]] crash in 1991. ==Early life and education== Koch was born in [[Wichita, Kansas]], the son of Mary Clementine (née Robinson) and [[Fred C. Koch|Fred Chase Koch]], a chemical engineer. David's paternal grandfather, [[Harry Koch (businessman)|Harry Koch]], was a Dutch immigrant who founded the Quanah Tribune-Chief newspaper and was a founding shareholder of [[Quanah, Acme and Pacific Railway]].{{cite web |url=http://www.nnp.org/nni/Publications/Dutch-American/kochd.htm |title=Koch, David Hamilton (1940) |publisher=New Netherland Project |accessdate=August 31, 2010}} David is the third of four sons, with elder brothers [[Frederick R. Koch]], Charles Koch, and nineteen-minute younger twin [[Bill Koch (businessman)|Bill Koch]]. Among his maternal great-great-grandparents were [[William Ingraham Kip]], an Episcopalian bishop, [[William Burnet Kinney]], a politician, and [[Elizabeth Clementine Stedman]], a writer. Koch attended the [[Deerfield Academy]] prep school in Massachusetts, graduating in 1959. He went on to the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] (MIT), earning both a [[bachelor's degree|bachelor's]] (1962) and a [[master's degree]] (1963) in [[chemical engineering]]. He is a member of the [[Beta Theta Pi]] Fraternity. Koch played basketball at MIT, averaging 21 points per game at MIT over three years, a school record. He also held the single-game scoring record of 41 points from 1962 until 2009, when it was eclipsed by [[Jimmy Bartolotta]].{{Cite journal|url=https://newrepublic.com/article/114135/david-and-william-koch-mit-basketball-players |title=David and William Koch as MIT Basketball Players |journal=The New Republic |date=August 14, 2013 |accessdate=June 10, 2015}} ==Career at Koch Industries== In 1970, Koch joined [[Koch Industries]] under his brother Charles, to work as a technical-services manager. He founded the company's New York office and in 1979 he became the president of his own division, Koch Engineering, renamed Chemical Technology Group. In 1985, Koch Industries was sued by [[Bill Koch (businessman)|Bill Koch]] and [[Frederick R. Koch]] for the first time in a long series of lawsuits about ownership, that lasted until 2001. As of 2010, David Koch owned 42 percent of Koch Industries, as does his brother Charles. He holds 4 U.S patents. On June 5, 2018, the company announced his retirement from the company due to declining health issues.{{cite web |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/powerpost/wp/2018/06/05/david-koch-is-leaving-koch-industries-stepping-down-from-americans-for-prosperity/|title=David Koch is leaving Koch Industries, stepping down from Americans for Prosperity|first=James|last=Hohmann |date=June 5, 2018|publisher=|accessdate=June 5, 2018|via=www.washingtonpost.com}} ==Political career== Koch was the [[United States Libertarian Party|Libertarian Party]]'s [[Vice President of the United States|vice-presidential]] candidate in the [[U.S. presidential election, 1980|1980 presidential election]],{{cite news |title=Man Without a Candidate |authorlink=Charlotte Curtis |first=Charlotte |last=Curtis |date=October 16, 1984 |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/16/arts/man-without-a-candidate.html |accessdate=July 18, 2015}} sharing the party ticket with [[President of the United States|presidential]] candidate [[Ed Clark]]. The Clark–Koch [[Ticket (election)|ticket]] promised to abolish [[Social Security (United States)|Social Security]], the [[Federal Reserve Board]], [[welfare]], [[minimum-wage]] laws, corporate taxes, all price supports and subsidies for agriculture and business, and [[U.S. Federal agencies]] including the SEC, EPA, ICC, FTC, OSHA, FBI, CIA, and DOE.Rinker Buck, [https://books.google.com/books?id=ueUCAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PA18&dq=David%20Koch&pg=PA22#v=onepage&q=David%20Koch&f=false "How Those Libertarians Pay the Bills"], [[New York (magazine)|''New York'' magazine]], November 3, 1980 The ticket received 921,128 votes, 1% of the total nationwide vote,{{cite web|url=http://uselectionatlas.org/RESULTS/national.php?year=1980&off=0&f=1|title=1980 Presidential General Election Results|author=David Leip|work=uselectionatlas.org}} the Libertarian Party national ticket's best showing until [[U.S. presidential election, 2016|2016]] in terms of percentage and its best showing in terms of raw votes until the [[U.S. presidential election, 2012|2012 presidential election]], although that number was surpassed again in 2016.James T. Bennett, [https://books.google.com/books?id=eImBSPX63D0C&pg=PA167&dq=ed+clark+highest+vote+total+1980&hl=en&ei=YZB9TMd3goHyBufjrZkH&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CDcQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=ed%20clark%20highest%20vote%20total%201980&f=false ''Not Invited to the Party: How the Demopublicans Have Rigged the System and Left Independents Out in the Cold''], Springer, 2009, p. 167, {{ISBN|1-4419-0365-8}}.{{cite news |title=Quixotic '80 Campaign Gave Birth to Kochs' Powerful Network |authorlink=Nicholas Confessore |first=Nicholas |last=Confessore |date=May 17, 2014 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/05/18/us/politics/quixotic-80-campaign-gave-birth-to-kochs-powerful-network.html |accessdate=July 18, 2015 |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] }} "Compared to what [the Libertarians had] gotten before," Charles said, "and where we were as a movement or as a political/ideological point of view, that was pretty remarkable, to get 1 percent of the vote."{{cite news|first=Matthew |last=Continetti|authorlink=Matthew Continetti|title=The Paranoid Style in Liberal Politics|work=[[The Weekly Standard]]|date=April 4, 2011|url=http://www.weeklystandard.com/articles/paranoid-style-liberal-politics_555525.html}} After the bid, according to journalist [[Brian Doherty (journalist)|Brian Doherty]]'s ''[[Radicals for Capitalism]]'', Koch viewed politicians as "actors playing out a script".{{cite book|last=Doherty|first=Brian |authorlink=Brian Doherty (journalist)|title=Radicals for Capitalism: A Freewheeling History of the Modern American Libertarian Movement|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6g_NGAAACAAJ|accessdate=October 10, 2011|date=May 26, 2008|publisher=Perseus Books Group|isbn=978-1-58648-572-6|page=410}} Koch credits the campaign of [[Roger MacBride]] as his inspiration for getting involved in politics:
Here was a great guy, advocating all the things I believed in. He wanted less government and taxes, and was talking about repealing all these victimless crime laws that accumulated on the books. I have friends who smoke pot. I know many homosexuals. It's ridiculous to treat them as criminals—and here was someone running for president, saying just that.
Koch gave his own Vice Presidential campaign $100,000 a month after being chosen as [[Ed Clark]]'s running mate. "We'd like to abolish the [[Federal Elections Commission]] and all the limits on campaign spending anyway," Koch said in 1980. When asked why he ran, he replied: "Lord knows I didn't need a job, but I believe in what the Libertarians are saying. I suppose if they hadn't come along, I could have been a big Republican from [[Wichita, Kansas|Wichita]]. But hell—''everybody'' from Kansas is a Republican." In 1984 he broke with the Libertarian Party when it supported eliminating all taxes. Since then, Koch has been a [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]].{{rp|4}} == Politics == {{see also|Political activities of the Koch brothers}} ===Political views=== Koch considers himself a [[Cultural liberalism|social liberal]],{{cite web |url=http://abcnews.go.com/blogs/politics/2014/12/billionaire-david-koch-says-hes-a-social-liberal/ |title=Billionaire David Koch Says He's a Social Liberal|work=ABC News|date=December 14, 2014|accessdate=December 29, 2014|author=Bell, Benjamin}} supporting women's [[right to choose]],{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2014/12/14/politics/david-koch-gay-rights-abortion-democrats/ |title=David Koch is pro-choice, supports gay rights; just not Democrats|work=CNN|date=December 15, 2014 |accessdate=December 29, 2014|author=Fischer, Sara}} [[LGBT rights in the United States|gay rights]], [[same-sex marriage]] and [[stem-cell research]].Joseph Patrick McCormick, [http://www.pinknews.co.uk/2012/09/02/billionaire-gop-supporter-disagrees-with-platform-says-he-supports-gay-marriage/ Billionaire GOP supporter disagrees with platform, says he supports gay marriage], ''[[Pink News]]'', September 2, 2012 He opposes the [[war on drugs]].The Koch Brothers December 24, 2012 p. 96 Forbes Koch supports policies that promote [[individual liberty]] and [[free market]] principles, and supports reduced government spending.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/05/us/05koch.html|date=March 5, 2011 |publisher=The New York Times|title=Cancer Research Before Activism, Billionaire Conservative Donor Says|last=Cooper|first=Michael}} Koch supports a [[non-interventionist]] foreign policy; "Pursuing a very aggressive foreign policy," he says, "is an extremely expensive endeavor for the U.S. government. The cost of maintaining a huge military force abroad is gigantic. It's so big it puts a severe strain on the U.S. economy, creating economic hardships here at home."{{cite web |url=http://reason.com/archives/1987/02/01/the-new-antiwar-capitalists/print|title=The New Antiwar Capitalists|website=Reason.com}} Koch opposed the [[Iraq War]], saying that the war has "cost a lot of money and it's taken so many American lives", and "I question whether that was the right thing to do. In hindsight that looks like it was not a good policy". In an impromptu interview with the blog ThinkProgress, he was quoted as saying he would like the new Republican Congress to "cut the hell out of spending, balance the budget, reduce regulations, and support business."{{cite news |url=http://thinkprogress.org/politics/2011/01/06/137586/koch-teaparty-us/|publisher=ThinkProgress|date=January 6, 2011|last=Fang |first=Lee|title=Exclusive: Polluter Billionaire David Koch Says Tea Party 'Rank And File Are Just Normal People Like Us'}} He is against the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act and the Dodd–Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act.{{cite web|url=http://nymag.com/news/features/67285/|title=How Oil Heir and New York Arts Patron David Koch Became the Tea Party's Wallet |work=NYMag.com}} He is skeptical about anthropogenic [[global warming]]. He has said a warmer planet would be good because "Earth will be able to support enormously more people because a far greater land area will be available to produce food". Koch has many thoughts on several of President Obama's policies. An article from the ''Weekly Standard'', detailing the "left's obsession" with the Koch brothers, quotes Koch stating that Obama is "the most radical president we've ever had as a nation ... and has done more damage to the free enterprise system and long-term prosperity than any president we've ever had."{{cite web |url=http://www.weeklystandard.com/articles/paranoid-style-liberal-politics_555525.html?nopager=1|title=The Paranoid Style in Liberal Politics|work=weeklystandard.com}} Koch said that Obama's father's economic [[socialism]], practiced in [[Kenya]], explains why Obama has "sort of antibusiness and anti-free enterprise" influences. Koch said that Obama is "scary", a "hardcore socialist" who is "marvelous at pretending to be something other than that."{{cite news |url=http://nymag.com/daily/intel/2011/05/billionaire_conservative_david.html|title=David Koch Gives President Obama Zero Credit for Bin Laden's Death|publisher=New York|first=Sarah|last=Owen|date=May 5, 2011}} Koch contributed to both Republicans and Democrats in 2012, with the majority of his contributions going to Republican candidates.{{cite web |url=https://www.motherjones.com/politics/2012/11/charts-map-koch-brothers-2012-spending|title=Charts: How Much Have the Kochs Spent on the 2012 Election?|work=Mother Jones}} === Political advocacy === {{see also|Political activities of the Koch brothers}} In 1984, Koch founded, served as Chairman of the [[board of directors]] of, and donated to the [[Free market|free-market]] [[Citizens for a Sound Economy]] (CSE). [[Richard H. Fink]] served as its first president. Koch is Chairman of the Board and gave initial funding to the [[Americans for Prosperity|Americans for Prosperity Foundation]] and to a related advocacy organization, [[Americans for Prosperity]]. A Koch Industries spokesperson issued a press release stating "No funding has been provided by Koch companies, the Koch foundations, or Charles Koch or David Koch specifically to support the tea parties."{{cite web|url=http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2010/08/30/covert-operations|title=Covert Operations|author=Jane Mayer|date=August 30, 2010 |work=The New Yorker}}{{cite news |url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/right-now/2010/04/dick_armey_please_koch_keep_di.html |author=Weigel, David |title=Dick Armey: Please, Koch, keep distancing yourself from me |agency=Washington Post |date=April 15, 2010}} Koch was the top initial funder of the Americans for Prosperity Foundation at $850,000.{{cite news |title=David Koch Seeded Major Tea-Party Group, Private Donor List Reveals |first=Alex |last=Seitz-Wald |date=September 24, 2013 |accessdate=March 20, 2015 |url=http://www.nationaljournal.com/politics/david-koch-seeded-major-tea-party-group-private-donor-list-reveals-20130924 |publisher=[[National Journal]] |quote=But a donor list filed with the IRS labeled "not open for public inspection" from 2003, the year of AFP's first filing, lists David Koch as by far the single largest contributor to its foundation, donating $850,000.}}{{cite news |title=Money In Politics: The Companies Behind David Koch's Americans For Prosperity |first=Pema |last=Levy |date=September 24, 2013 |accessdate=March 20, 2015 |url=http://www.ibtimes.com/money-politics-companies-behind-david-kochs-americans-prosperity-1410408 |publisher=[[International Business Times]] |quote=David Koch was the top contributor, providing $850,000.}} Koch said that he sympathizes with the [[Tea Party movement]], but denies directly supporting it, stating: "I've never been to a tea party event. No one representing the tea party has ever even approached me." Koch sits on the board and donates to the libertarian [[Cato Institute]] and [[Reason Foundation]].{{cite journal |url=http://www.newyorker.com/reporting/2010/08/30/100830fa_fact_mayer |title=Covert Operations: The billionaire brothers who are waging a war against Obama |journal=[[The New Yorker]] |date=August 30, 2010 |first=Jane |last=Mayer |authorlink=Jane Mayer }}{{cite journal |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB125064719500442047 |title=Conservatives Take a Page From Left's Online Playbook |journal=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |date=August 20, 2009 |first=Jake |last=Sherman}} In February 2012, during the [[Wisconsin gubernatorial recall election]], Koch said of Wisconsin governor [[Scott Walker (politician)|Scott Walker]], "We're helping him, as we should. We've gotten pretty good at this over the years. We've spent a lot of money in Wisconsin. We're going to spend more," and said that by "we" he meant Americans for Prosperity.{{cite news |title=David Koch intends to cure cancer in his lifetime and remake American politics |date=February 20, 2012 |accessdate=May 29, 2015 |newspaper=[[The Palm Beach Post]] |url=http://www.palmbeachpost.com/news/business/david-koch-intends-to-cure-cancer-in-his-lifetime-/nL4Fb/ |first=Stacey |last=Singer}}{{cite news |magazine=[[The Nation]] |authorlink=John Nichols (journalist) |first=John |last=Nichols |title=Scott Walker's Koch Connection Goes Bad |date=February 24, 2012 |accessdate=May 29, 2015 |url=http://www.thenation.com/blog/166450/scott-walkers-koch-connection-goes-bad}}{{cite web |title=Billionaire Koch brothers gave $8 million to Wisconsin Gov. |url=http://newsdesk.si.edu/releases/smithsonian-s-national-museum-natural-history-build-new-dinosaur-hall |title=Smithsonian's National Museum of Natural History to Build New Dinosaur Hall | Newsdesk |publisher=Newsdesk.si.edu |date=May 3, 2012 |accessdate=June 10, 2015}}{{Cite news|title = David Koch donates $35 million to National Museum of Natural History for dinosaur hall|url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/style/david-koch-donates-35-million-to-national-museum-of-natural-history-for-dinosaur-hall/2012/05/03/gIQAIjT3yT_story.html|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=May 3, 2012|accessdate=January 24, 2016 |issn=0190-8286|language=en-US|first=Jacqueline|last=Trescott}} Koch also financed the construction of the $68 million Koch Center for mathematics, science and technology at the [[Deerfield Academy]], a highly selective [[Independent school|independent]], [[coeducational]] [[boarding school]] at [[Deerfield, Massachusetts]],{{cite news |url=http://scroll.deerfield.edu/?p=3032 |title=David Koch Named Lifetime Trustee |agency=Deerfield Scroll |date=February 25, 2010 |author=Cobbs, Lucy }}{{Primary source inline|reason=secondary source needed for noteworthiness|date=July 2015}} and was named its first and only Lifetime Trustee. Koch gave $10 million to the [[Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory]] {{Cite web|title = The Koch Brothers' Ten Most Shocking Power Grabs|url=http://thefederalist.com/2015/02/02/the-koch-brothers-ten-most-shocking-power-grabs/|accessdate=February 14, 2016 |last=Media|date=2015-02-02}} where he was honored with the [[Double Helix Medal]] for Corporate Leadership for supporting research that, "improves the health of people everywhere".{{cite web |url=http://www.cshl.edu/news-a-features/31-million-raised-at-cold-spring-harbor-laboratorys-2007-double-helix-medals-dinner.html |title= $3.1 Million Raised at Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory's 2007 Double Helix Medals Dinner |date=November 21, 2007}}{{Primary source inline|reason=secondary source needed for noteworthiness|date=July 2015}} ===Prison reform=== In July 2015 David Koch and his brother were commended by both President Obama and activist [[Van Jones|Anthony Van Jones]] for their bipartisan efforts to reform the prison system in the United States.{{cite web|last=Nelson|first=Colleen Mccain; Fields, Gary |title=Obama, Koch Brothers in Unlikely Alliance to Overhaul Criminal Justice|work=Wall Street Journal|date=July 16, 2015 |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/obama-koch-brothers-in-unlikely-alliance-to-overhaul-criminal-justice-1437090737}}{{cite web|last=Horwitz|first=Sari|title=Unlikely Allies|work=Washington Post|date=August 15, 2015 |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/sf/national/2015/08/15/clemency-the-issue-that-obama-and-the-koch-brothers-actually-agree-on/}} For nearly ten years the Kochs have been advocating for several reforms within the criminal justice system which include reducing recidivism rates, simplifying the employment process for the rehabilitated, and defending private property from government seizures through [[asset forfeiture]].{{cite web|url=http://cjonline.com/news/2015-10-15/forfeiture-reform-aligns-likes-billionaire-charles-koch-aclu |title=Forfeiture reform aligns likes of billionaire Charles Koch, ACLU|work=The Topeka Capital Journal |date=October 15, 2015|author=Hudetz, Mary}} Allying with groups such as the [[ACLU]], the [[Center for American Progress]], [[Families Against Mandatory Minimums]], the [[Coalition for Public Safety]], and the [[John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation|MacArthur Foundation]], the Kochs maintain the current prison system unfairly targets low-income and minority communities at the expense of the public budget.{{cite web|title=Koch brothers join Obama in advocating US prison reform|work=Russian Today|date=July 17, 2015|url=https://www.rt.com/usa/310128-koch-brothers-obama-prisons/}} == Criticism and recognition== In August 2010, [[Jane Mayer]] wrote an article in ''[[The New Yorker]]'' on the political spending of David and Charles Koch stating: "As their fortunes grew, Charles and David Koch became the primary underwriters of hard-line libertarian politics in America." Mayer's article was criticized by conservatives for not enumerating the Kochs' charitable donations.{{cite web|url=http://www.politicsdaily.com/2010/09/02/koch-brothers-give-more-to-charity-than-to-right-wing-causes |title=Koch Brothers Donate to Charity as well as Right Wing Causes |last=Lewis |first=Matt |date=September 2, 2010 |publisher=[[AOL News]] |work=[[Politics Daily]] |accessdate=March 18, 2015}} Mayer's article was also criticized by Koch Industries as using "psycho-biographic innuendo, unnamed sources, and half-truths".{{cite web|last=Nick|first=Gillespie|title=The Official Koch Industries Reply to The New Yorker Hit Piece|url=http://reason.com/blog/2010/08/25/the-official-koch-industries-r|work=reason.com|publisher=reason.com|accessdate=October 10, 2011|date=2010-08-25}} An opinion piece by journalist [[Yasha Levine]] in the ''[[New York Observer]]'' said Mayer's article failed to mention that the Kochs' "free market philanthropy belies the immense profit they have made from corporate welfare".{{cite news |url=http://observer.com/2010/09/7-ways-the-koch-bros-benefit-from-corporate-welfare/ |last=Levine |first=Yasha |authorlink=Yasha Levine|date=September 1, 2010| title=7 Ways the Koch Bros. Benefit from Corporate Welfare|publisher=New York Observer |accessdate=December 30, 2014}} Kimberly O. Dennis, president and chief executive officer of the [[Searle Freedom Trust]],{{cite web |url=http://bov.gmu.edu/bios/dennis.html|title=George Mason University Board of Visitors: Kimberly Dennis|accessdate=December 30, 2014}} said in 2010 that the Kochs are acting against their economic interest in promoting "getting government out of the business of running the economy. If they were truly interested in protecting their profits, they wouldn't be spending so much to shrink government; they'd be looking for a bigger slice of the pie for themselves. Their funding is devoted to promoting free-market capitalism, not crony capitalism."{{cite web |url=http://www.nationalreview.com/corner/253323/democrats-cant-blame-koch-brothers-however-much-they-might-want-kimberly-o-dennis |title=Democrats Can't Blame the Koch Brothers (However Much They Might Want To) |last=Dennis |first=Kimberly O. |date=November 15, 2010 |publisher=[[National Review Online]] |accessdate=January 31, 2011}}{{Primary source inline|reason=evidence of significant coverage of this view in reliable sources? WP:DUE: "Generally, the views of tiny minorities should not be included at all" |date=June 2015}} In 2011 ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' included Charles and David Koch among the [[Time 100]] of the year, for their involvement in supporting the [[Tea Party movement]] and the criticism they received from liberals.{{cite news|last=Ferguson|first=Andrew|title=The 2011 TIME 100|url=http://www.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,2066367_2066369_2066324,00.html|work=TIME|accessdate=April 22, 2011 |date=April 21, 2011}} ==Personal life== Koch married Julia Flesher in 1996.{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/11/magazine/woman-ascending-a-marble-staircase.html?pagewanted=all |title=Woman Ascending A Marble Staircase |author=Elizabeth Bumiller |publisher=The New York Times |date=January 11, 1998 |accessdate=August 31, 2010}}{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/26/style/weddings-julia-m-flesher-david-h-koch.html |title=Weddings: Julia M. Flesher, David H. Koch |author=NYT staff |publisher=The New York Times |work=Style |date=May 26, 1996 |accessdate=September 2, 2010}} He has 3 children. In 1992, Koch was diagnosed with [[prostate cancer]]. He underwent radiation, surgery, and hormone therapy, but the cancer has returned every time. Koch has said he believes his experience with cancer has encouraged him to fund medical research. ==See also== * [[List of billionaires]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{C-SPAN|davidkoch}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20101103024037/http://www.influenceexplorer.com/individual/koch-david/741672ab1e0a4314be416ce3cfc2afbc Political contributions] from ''Influence Explorer'' at the [[Sunlight Foundation]] * [http://www.followthemoney.org/press/ReportView.phtml?r=434 Names in the News: David and Charles Koch] at FollowTheMoney.org * [http://topics.nytimes.com/topics/reference/timestopics/people/k/david_h_koch Collected news and commentary] at ''[[The New York Times]]'' * {{cite book|url=http://sonsofwichita.com/|author=Daniel Schulman|title=Sons of Wichita|publisher=Grand Central Publishing|isbn=978-1455518739|date=May 20, 2014}} {{s-start}} {{s-ppo}} {{s-bef|before=[[David Bergland]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Libertarian Party (United States)|Libertarian]] [[List of United States Libertarian Party presidential tickets|nominee]] for [[Vice President of the United States]]|years=[[United States presidential election, 1980|1980]]}} {{s-aft|after=[[James A.
