:''This article is about John '''Langdon''' Bonython (1905−1992)'' :''His father was named [[John Lavington Bonython|Sir John '''Lavington''' Bonython]] (1875−1960)'' :''His grandfather was named [[John Langdon Bonython|Sir John '''Langdon''' Bonython]] (1848−1939)''
'''John Langdon Bonython''' [[Officer of the Order of Australia|AO]] (13 January 1905{{spaced ndash}}1992), was a prominent [[Adelaide]] businessman.
==Family== Bonython was born into the "Old Adelaide Family" Bonython. His grandfather was [[John Langdon Bonython]].<ref name=langdon>W. B. Pitcher, [http://www.adb.online.anu.edu.au/biogs/A070345b.htm Bonython, Sir John Langdon (1848 - 1939)], Australian Dictionary of Biography, Volume 7, Melbourne University Press, 1979, pp 339-341.</ref> His father was [[John Lavington Bonython]].<ref name=lavington>W. B. Pitcher, [http://www.adb.online.anu.edu.au/biogs/A070346b.htm Bonython, Sir John Lavington (1875 - 1960)], Australian Dictionary of Biography, Volume 7, Melbourne University Press, 1979, pp 341-342.</ref> His mother was Blanche Ada Bray. He had two sisters, two half-brothers ([[Warren Bonython]] and [[Kym Bonython]]), and one half-sister.
He married Minnie Hope Rutherford in 1926 and they had three children.<ref name=rootsweb>[http://archiver.rootsweb.ancestry.com/th/read/AUS-SAGEN/2007-08/1186301170 John Bonython AO (b. 1905) of Santos Oil], rootsweb.com</ref>
==Biography==
John Langdon Bonython was born on 13 January 1905 in [[Adelaide]], SA, Australia.<ref name=RC/><ref name=jlb1905/>
He studied at the [[University of Adelaide]], and became a solicitor in 1930.<ref name=RC>Richard Carruthers, "Family tree, Richard Carruthers", 1986.</ref><ref name=jlb1905>{{cite web|url=http://users.cyberone.com.au/nevmoya/bray%20families2-o/p21.htm#i7827 |title=John Langdon Bonython |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120720054800/http://users.cyberone.com.au/nevmoya/bray%20families2-o/p21.htm%23i7827 |archivedate=20 July 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }}, cyberzone.com</ref>
Chaired Advertiser Newspapers Ltd.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=EDgPo8KWKh4C "The Wakefield Companion to South Australian History"] by Wilfrid R. Prest, Kerrie Round, Carol S. Fort, Wakefield Press, 2001, pg.79. {{ISBN|1-86254-558-8}}, {{ISBN|978-1-86254-558-8}}, 688 pages</ref>
On 18 March 1954, he became the founding Chairman of the first board of directors of [[Santos Limited]].<ref name=Santos/>
In 1982 a deep water port facility at Stony Point 20 km north of [[Whyalla]] was connected to the [[Moomba Adelaide Pipeline System]], a 659 km pipeline from [[Moomba, South Australia|Moomba]] in the [[Cooper Basin]]; this facility was named [[Port Bonython]] in his honour.<ref name=rootsweb/><ref name=Santos>[http://www.santos.com/Content.aspx?p=82 Historical highlights] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081219011543/http://www.santos.com/Content.aspx?p=82 |date=19 December 2008 }}, Santos.com</ref>
==Awards== On 9 June 1980 he was appointed an Officer of the [[Order of Australia]], "in recognition of service to media and to industry".<ref>[http://www.itsanhonour.gov.au/honours/honour_roll/search.cfm?aus_award_id=870971&search_type=simple&showInd=true It's an Honour]</ref>
In 1986, the suburb of [[Bonython, Australian Capital Territory|Bonython]] in Tuggeranong, [[Australian Capital Territory]] was [[gazetteer|gazetted]] in his honour.<ref>Canberra's suburb and street names : origins and meanings. Department of the Environment, Land and Planning. 1992. p. 6. {{ISBN|1-86331-128-9}}.</ref>
==References and notes== {{Reflist}}

'''Josephine Porter Crane''' (née Boardman; November 14, 1873 – July 8, 1972) was an American socialite and patron of the arts, co-founder and original trustee of the [[Museum of Modern Art]] and supporter of the [[Dalton School]] of [[New York City]].<ref name=Obituary>{{cite news|last=Obituary|title=Josephine Crane dies in Falmouth|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1972/07/09/91335274.pdf|accessdate=April 11, 2012|newspaper=New York Times|date=July 8, 1972}}</ref>
==Personal life== {{more citations needed|section|date=October 2016}} Born Josephine Porter Boardman, in [[Cleveland, Ohio]], she was from a well-to-do family. Her father, William Jarvis Boardman (April 15, 1832 – August 2. 1915), a lawyer and political activist, was the grandson of United States Senator [[Elijah Boardman]]. Her mother, Florence Sheffield, was the granddaughter of [[Joseph Earl Sheffield]], a major benefactor of Yale University. She had five siblings, including [[Mabel Thorp Boardman]]. The family moved from Ohio to Washington, D.C. in 1887-8, although they maintained connections to Ohio politics including a friendship with the [[Taft family]].
In 1906, she married [[Winthrop Murray Crane]], an American millionaire 20 years her senior, a former [[governor of Massachusetts]] and [[US Senator]], with whom she had three children: Stephen, [[Bruce Crane (businessman)|Bruce]], and [[Louise Crane|Louise]]. Winthrop M. Crane died in 1920. After the Senator's death, she moved to New York City, where she was a founder of the [[Museum of Modern Art]] and was elected to the board of trustees in October 1929.<ref name=Obituary/>
Crane was the benefactress of the prestigious [[Dalton School]], which took its name from the location of the Crane family estate, "Sugar Hill", in [[Dalton, Massachusetts]]. She was the original sponsor for implementing the [[Dalton Plan]] in 1920,<ref name="HighSchool">{{cite book|last=Parkhurst|first=Helen|authorlink=Helen Parkhurst|title=Education On The Dalton Plan|url=https://archive.org/details/educationontheda028244mbp|accessdate=2007-12-01|year=1922|publisher=E.P. Dutton & Company|location=New York|pages=15–16}}</ref> a much-copied experiment in education.
Crane hosted a weekly literary salon at her apartment at [[820 Fifth Avenue]], [[New York City]] and at the family home on Penzance Point, [[Woods Hole]], [[Massachusetts]]. Guests included [[Marianne Moore]] and [[William Somerset Maugham]].<ref name=Obituary/>
==Death and legacy== She died of [[pneumonia]] on July 8, 1972, aged 98, at [[Falmouth Hospital]] in [[Falmouth, Massachusetts]].<ref name=Obituary/>
The '''Josephine B. Crane Foundation''' continues to support the [[Sierra Club]], scientific research and various [[scholarship]]s.
==Published work== * Crane, Boardman Josephine. ''A Middle-west Child'' New York: Spiral Press (1971)<!-- ISSN/ISBN needed -->
==Donations== * [http://www.metmuseum.org/Works_of_Art/viewOne.asp?dep=11&viewmode=1&item=69.280.4] Gift of Mrs. W. Murray Crane, 1969 *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110603235202/http://americanhistory.si.edu/collections/costume/object.cfm?recordnumber=365574] Mrs. Crane donated a number of items from her sister's (Mrs. Frederick Keep) estate to the [[Smithsonian Institution]]. Exhibited in the Hall of American Costume from 1964-73. *[http://www.moma.org/collection/browse_results.php?criteria=O%3ACL%3AI%3A10&page_number=37&template_id=1&sort_order=1] Sculpture gift of Mrs. W. Murray Crane.

{{Infobox person | name ='''Jose Juan Garcia''' | residence = | other_names ='''"CheJuan"''' | image =Cheguan.JPG | imagesize = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date =October 22, 1940 | birth_place =[[Rio Piedras, Puerto Rico]] | death_date =December 17, 2002 | death_place =[[San Juan, Puerto Rico]] | known = Founder of [[Hogares Crea]] | job = | title = | religion = | spouse = Flora Rosario Johnson, Ramonita "Monín" Beltrán-Rivera | partner = | children = José Javier Garcia Beltrán | website = | employer = }}
'''Jose Juan Garcia''' a.k.a. '''CheJuan''' (October 22, 1940 – December 17, 2002) was the founder of the international institution called [[Hogares Crea]].
==Early years== Garcia was born in [[San Juan, Puerto Rico|Rio Piedras, Puerto Rico]] where he was raised by his parents. He had a tough childhood and experienced his first imprisonment when he was 15 years old. At a very young age, he became a drug addict and stole in order to pay for his habit. He went to prison more than once because of his drug problems. However, he was fortunate enough to have met some people who would have a positive influence in his live and change it forever, among them was the educator [[Ana G. Mendez]]. He also attributed his acceptance of "[[Christ]]" as a reason for his change.<ref>[http://www.biblesociety.org/sr_19/sr_19.htm#Drug Center Drug Center Biblesociety]</ref>
=="Hogares Crea"== In 1968, Garcia founded in [[Puerto Rico]] "Hogares Crea". The word "Crea" stands for the re-education of the addict and the community. Those who enter the program do not have to pay a fee, but, must agree to the programs strict rules. Breaking a drug habit is not easy and those who enter the program must adopt new habits which are conductive to recovery. They must go to church on Sundays and sell caramel custards and garbage bags door to door. They also must wash cars and do community services.<ref>[http://www.puertorico-herald.org/issues/2003/vol7n28/HogarCrea-en.html Puerto Rico Herald] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927203736/http://www.puertorico-herald.org/issues/2003/vol7n28/HogarCrea-en.html |date=2007-09-27 }}</ref>
Garcia's program is not financed by the government. [[Physician|Doctor]]s, [[psychologist]]s and others donate their time. Expenses are covered by the volunteer board of each home. Each home has enough beds for 15 people. 28 thousand people have successfully completed the program, out of 51 thousand addicts who have been treated in 36 years. In is estimated that 92% of those who have completed the program started by Garcia, have completely stayed out of drugs.<ref>[http://www.ich.gov/newsletter/archive/02-23-06_e-newsletter.htm HOGAR CREA DELIVERS INNOVATIVE APPROACH TO RECOVERY]</ref>
Garcia's Hogares Crea have over 152 facilities worldwide. Some of the other countries besides Puerto Rico, where Hogares Crea are established are: the [[United States]], [[Dominican Republic]], [[Costa Rica]], [[Venezuela]], [[Colombia]], [[Panama]], [[El Salvador]], [[Honduras]] and [[Nicaragua]]. <ref>[http://www.puertorico-herald.org/issues/2002/vol6n52/HogarCrea-en.html Hogar CREA: A Struggle To Stay Clean, To Save Souls]</ref>
==Awards and recognitions== Among the awards and recognitions he received are: * The Citizen of the Year in 1974, Granted by the Puerto Rico Manufacturers Association * Citizen of the Year 1976, by the Puerto Rico Chamber of Commerce * An award from [[Ronald Reagan|President Ronald Reagan]] and others for the exemplary community service offered by Hogar CREA in the United States. * The [[Government of Puerto Rico]] named a plaza in Rio Piedras "Plaza Jose Juan "Cheguan" Garcia".
==Later years== Jose Juan Garcia died on December 22, 2002 in [[San Juan, Puerto Rico]] from [[cancer]]. His son Javier Garcia and his widow Flora Rosario Johnson were involved in a dispute over the control of the organization. The organizations current director is Benjamin Pintor Miranda.<ref>[http://www.lexjuris.com/lexlex/lex97133.htm Public Law #133] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061022051854/http://www.lexjuris.com/lexlex/lex97133.htm |date=2006-10-22 }}</ref>

{{EngvarB|date=April 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2017}} {{Infobox person | name = Kutubuddin Ahmed | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1956|1|21}} | birth_place = | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|df=yes|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (death date then birth date) --> | death_place = | nationality = | other_names = | occupation = Businessman | years_active = | known_for = | notable_works = }}
'''Kutubuddin Ahmed''' (born 1956) is a [[Bangladesh]]i businessman who is the founder and chairman of the Envoy Group,<ref name="ds5Dec2014" /> a conglomerate which operates in multiple sectors, with major operation in the apparel industry.<ref name="reuters">[http://uk.reuters.com/article/2013/10/20/uk-bangladesh-politics-idUKBRE99J03520131020 "Elections in jeopardy as Bangladesh parties head for showdown"]. ''Reuters'', 20 October 2013, DHAKA | By Shyamantha Asokan and Serajul Quadir</ref> He is a Fellow of the Institute of Engineers, Bangladesh. In 2015 he is a member of the executive committee of the International Chamber of Commerce, Bangladesh, and a director of the Chittagong Stock Exchange.{{citation needed|date=September 2016}}
==Early life and education== Ahmed was born on 21 January 1956 in [[Dhaka]]. He graduated in mechanical engineering from [[Bangladesh University of Engineering and Technology]] (BUET).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.iccbangladesh.org.bd/committee/details/kutubuddin-ahmed |title=Executive Board: Kutubuddin Ahmed |website=International Chamber of Commerce Bangladesh |access-date=9 July 2017}}</ref>
==Business career== Ahmed began his career at [[Janata Bank]], but resigned in 1983 to start his own business. Raising the BDT 10 lakh (US$37,500 in 1984) initial capital for what is now known as the [[Envoy Group]] proved difficult. In the end, Ahmed took out a bank loan with his father's house as collateral and brought in a partner, [[Abdus Salam Murshedy]],<ref name="ds20May2017">{{cite news |last=Mirdha |first=Refayet Ullah |date=20 May 2017 |title=Fortune favours the brave |url=http://www.thedailystar.net/supplements/fortune-favours-the-brave-1407907 |newspaper=The Daily Star |access-date=9 July 2017}}</ref> a [[striker (football)|striker]] for [[Mohammedan Sporting Club (Dhaka)|Mohammedan Sporting Club]] who had gained fame in 1982 by scoring a league-record 27 goals, but who had no previous business experience.<ref>{{cite news |title=Wedson's near miss |url=http://www.thedailystar.net/wedsons-near-miss-34787 |newspaper=The Daily Star |date=25 July 2014 |access-date=9 July 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.envoy-group.com/md-profile.php |title=Managing Director's Profile: Abdus Salam Murshedy |website=Envoy Group |access-date=9 July 2017}}</ref>
In 1984, the partners set up a small factory in the [[Khilgaon Thana]] area of Dhaka, equipped it with 46 sewing machines, and hired 200 garment workers. Initially the company sub-contracted for other garment manufacturers.<ref name="ds20May2017" /> They were early participants in a sector that would become a powerhouse of the Bangladesh economy,<ref name="ds5Dec2014">{{cite news |last=Mirdha |first=Refayet Ullah |date=5 December 2014 |title=From baby steps to giant strides |url=http://www.thedailystar.net/from-baby-steps-to-giant-strides-53432 |newspaper=The Daily Star |access-date=9 July 2017}}</ref> but orders were sporadic at first, and the factory was idle for long spells. Sometimes they had to borrow from banks to meet payroll. The turning point came when they received their first order as a primary contractor, 6,500 trousers for a Swedish retailer.<ref name="ds20May2017" />
The agent who placed the order was impressed with their work and directed more business their way. In the next 16 months, Envoy Group recorded a BDT 1 crore (US$385,000 in 1985) profit. They paid off their debt and bought two more garment factories, building on the experience gained running their first.<ref name="ds20May2017" />
Through expansion, by attracting investment and purchasing existing businesses, Ahmed led the company as it grew over the years into a large manufacturing and exporting group.<ref>[http://www.thedailystar.net/business/envoy-textiles-raises-tk-70cr-through-commercial-papers-1205938 "Envoy Textiles raises Tk 70cr through commercial papers"]. ''The Daily Star'', 8 April 2016</ref>
Ahmed completed a term as President in Metropolitan Chamber of Commerce and Industry (MCCI), Dhaka and Bangladesh Garment Manufacturers & Exporters Association (BGMEA) in 2001 and 2002.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/1482751.stm "Inquiry into Dhaka stampede"]. ''BBC News''. Kamal Ahmed</ref><ref>[http://www.sdnbd.org/sdi/news/general-news/July/21-07-2002/Business.htm "Businessmen urged to capture global market"]. Chittagong, ''The Daily Star'', as reprinted in ''Sustainable Network Development Network'', Business news, 21 July 2002</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Textile Asia|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=39y5AAAAIAAJ|year=2003|publisher=Business Press|page=114}} Volume 34, Issues 1–6</ref>
He received the "Arthakantha Business Award-2002" by a national financial fortnightly of Bangladesh. He served as president (2004–2005) of the Metropolitan Chamber of Commerce and Industry (MCCI), Dhaka, Bangladesh<ref>[http://www.bangladesh-web.com/view.php?hidRecord=31015 "Kutubuddin Ahmed re-elected MCCI President"]. ''News from Bangladesh'' 31 December 2004</ref> He received an outstanding achievement award from International Islamic University Chittagong in 2008.
In 2014, Envoy Group had grown to include manufacturers and exporters garments,name=<ref name="reuters" /><ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/10/21/us-bangladesh-garments-wage-idUSBRE99K02M20131021 "Bangladesh poised to hike garment wages, but may not end strikes"]. ''Reuters'', DHAKA | By Shyamantha Asokan</ref> textiles,<ref>[http://www.denimsandjeans.com/news/interview-with-mr-kutubuddin-ahmed-chairman-envoy-textiles-limited/15854 "Interview With Mr Kutubuddin Ahmed | Chairman , Envoy Textiles Limited"]. ''Denims and Jeans'', SANDEEP AGGARWAL 13 September 2015</ref> Real Estate, Freight Forwarding, information technology and computer systems operations. At that time the company was employing about 20,000 people,<ref name="ds5Dec2014" /> and had received several awards, including the President's Export Trophy, and the National Export Trophy. In 2015, Ahmed was named a "commercially important person" by the government of Bangladesh.<ref>[http://archive.dhakatribune.com/business/2015/apr/28/56-individuals-get-cip-status-fy14 "56 individuals to get CIP status for FY14"]. ''Dhaka Tribune'', 28 April 2015</ref>
==Sports== Ahmed is a former President of both the Bangladesh Mohammedan Sporting Club, Dhaka, and the Bangladesh Badminton Federation. He was awarded 1997 "Sport Organizer of the Year" by Bangladesh Journalist Association, and received "National Sports Award 2002" for his contribution as a sports organiser in Bangladesh. In 2006 he was awarded the [[International Olympic Committee]] (IOC) Trophy for "Sports and the Community", and also Best Sports Organizer by Bangladesh Sports Writers' Association.<ref>[http://www.thedailystar.net/sports/pm-hands-out-sports-awards-1280392 "PM hands out sports awards for 2010, 2011 and 2012"]. ''Daily Star''. 4 September 2016</ref>
In 2009, Ahmed served as the secretary-general of the Bangladesh Olympic Association.<ref>[http://archive.indianexpress.com/news/cricket-to-feature-in-2010-south-asian-games/424632/ "Cricket to feature in 2010 South Asian Games"]. ''Reuters '' Dhaka, 17 February 2009.</ref> In 2014, he is a member of the Sports Environment Committee, Olympic Council of Asia (OCA), and the Vice-President of the International Military Sports Council (CISM).
==Community activity==
Ahmed formed "Saadat Smriti Sadan" charitable foundation in memory of his father Md. Saadat Ali. He established two Clinics which provide free medical treatment to the poor and distressed people. He set up a retirement home, ''Old-Homes'' for aged people over 65 years in Narshindi, Dhaka.
Ahmed funded the building of a Mosque at Nabi Nagar Thana, Comilla, and established a Technical Institute with computer accessories and sewing machinery tools in Narshindi for providing technical training. He is an advisor to the Campaign against Drug being run by the daily newspaper "Prothom Alo", and a member of the Advisory Council of the children's organisation 'Kendriya Kochi Kacher Mela'.

'''Marcel Louis Ospel''' (born 8 February 1950 in [[Basel]]) was a former Chairman of the Board of Directors of [[UBS AG]], the largest bank in [[Switzerland]].
Marcel Ospel had an income in 2005 of around 24 million [[Swiss Franc|CHF]].
After the company reported 19 billion U.S. dollar write-downs, Mr. Ospel was forced to withdraw his candidacy for re-election to the Board at the Annual General Meeting on 23 April 2008. It has been suggested that Ospel should be prosecuted for criminal negligence and gross mismanagement of UBS*[https://www.ubs.com/global/en/about_ubs/about_us/news.html]
== Timeline == * 1977-1980 Swiss Bank Corporation in the Central Planning and Marketing Division * 1980-1984 SBC London and New York in the Capital Markets division * 1984-1987 Managing Director with Merrill Lynch Capital Markets * 1987-1990 In charge of Securities Trading and Sales at SBC * 1990-1995 Member of the Executive Board of SBC * 1995-1996 CEO of SBC Warburg * 1996-1998 President and Group Chief Executive Officer of [[Swiss Bank Corporation]] (SBC) * 1999-2001 Group Chief Executive Officer, UBS AG * 2001-2008 Chairman of the Board of Directors, UBS AG
== Recognition == : '''2003''' marketing prize of ''Gesellschaft für Marketing'' for UBS world-wide single-brand strategy.
== Criticisms == In 2001, he was criticized for evading requests to extend [[Swissair]]'s line of credit, leading some people to believe that the dramatic grounding of Swissair planes on 2 October was Ospel's responsibility. These theories were later countered by information and details revealed in the media, and by the Swissair trial, held in 2007, which seemed to indicate otherwise.
==References== *Nolmans, Erik (Nov. 14, 2005). "UBS Fastens its Seatbelts". ''[[Fortune (magazine)|FORTUNE]]'', p. 20.

Overview (free company information from Companies House)|website=beta.companieshouse.gov.uk|access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref> | tax_id = <!-- or | vat_id = (for European organizations) --> | registration_id = <!-- for non-profit org --> | status = | purpose = | headquarters = | location = London, United Kingdom | coords = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LON|display=inline, title}} --> | region = | services = Entrepreneurship training | products = | methods = | fields = | membership = | membership_year = | language = | owner = <!-- or | owners = --> | sec_gen = | leader_title = | leader_name = | leader_title2 = | leader_name2 = | leader_title3 = | leader_name3 = | leader_title4 = | leader_name4 = | board_of_directors = | key_people = | main_organ = | parent_organization = | subsidiaries = | secessions = | affiliations = | budget = | budget_year = | revenue = | revenue_year = | disbursements = | expenses = | expenses_year = | endowment = | endowment_year = | staff = | staff_year = | volunteers = | volunteers_year = | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> | remarks = | formerly = | footnotes = }}
'''New Entrepreneurs Foundation''' (NEF), founded in 2010, is a London-based [[nonprofit organization]] that runs development programmes for aspiring [[Entrepreneurship|entrepreneurs]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.newentrepreneursfoundation.com|title=New Entrepreneurs Foundation|website=New Entrepreneurs Foundation|language=en-US|access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref>
==History== Founded in 2010 by Oliver Pawle, Dee Stirling, [[Nigel Rudd|Sir Nigel Rudd]] and [[Mervyn Davies, Baron Davies of Abersoch|The Lord Davies of Abersoch CBE]], the NEF was designed to support the next generation of UK entrepreneurs building new businesses.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://newentrepreneursfoundation.com/about-us-our-vision/|title=About Us - New Entrepreneurs Foundation|language=en-US|access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref>
In 2013, the organisation launched a guide for social entrepreneurs.<ref>https://www.theguardian.com/social-enterprise-network/2013/dec/19/new-guide-tips-advice-social-entrepreneur</ref>
In 2017, it was announced a new organisation would be set up by NEF and The Centre for Entrepreneurs to work on long-term challenges to entrepreneurship in the United Kingdom. One million pounds was donated to the project by [[Mikhail Fridman]].<ref>https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/oligarch-s-helping-hand-for-the-next-generation-bvpq20d9m</ref>
==Organisation== NEF solely focuses on the entrepreneurial potential of its intake rather than existing venture ideas.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://newentrepreneursfoundation.com/programme-explained/what-we-look-for/|title=What we look for - New Entrepreneurs Foundation|language=en-US|access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref> It does not require the contribution of equity from its participants’ ventures. It is entirely funded through corporate and individual sponsorship. See Sponsors and Funding for more information.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://newentrepreneursfoundation.com/our-sponsors/|title=Our sponsors - New Entrepreneurs Foundation|language=en-US|access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref>
Based in London the organisation's direction is decided by a [[Board of trustees|Board of Trustees]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://newentrepreneursfoundation.com/about-us-our-vision/our-leadership/|title=Our leadership - New Entrepreneurs Foundation|language=en-US|access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref> and CEO Neeta Patel.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://newentrepreneursfoundation.com/about-us-our-vision/executive-team/|title=Executive team - New Entrepreneurs Foundation|language=en-US|access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref>
== Courses == The NEF runs a yearly programme with up to fifty candidates. The candidates project can be anywhere from the ideas stage to running a venture full-time.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://studenttimes.org/article/news/graduate-news/forty-aspiring-entrepreneurs-be-selected-new-entrepreneur-training#.V56M66Ky47E|title=Forty Aspiring Entrepreneurs To Be Selected For New Entrepreneur Training Programme - Student Times|publisher=|accessdate=31 July 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://newentrepreneursfoundation.com/meet-class-of-2015/meet-our-alumni/|title=Meet our alumni - New Entrepreneurs Foundation|language=en-US|access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://newentrepreneursfoundation.com/programme-explained/faq/|title=FAQs - New Entrepreneurs Foundation|language=en-US|access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref>
The course has several components including:<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://newentrepreneursfoundation.com/programme-explained/|title=What is the NEF Programme? - The New Entrepreneurs Foundation|language=en-US|access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref>
* Paid Work Placement - placements with start-ups such as [[Secret Escapes]], [[Uber (company)|Uber]] and E-Leather.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://startups.co.uk/new-entrepreneurs-foundation-hunt-young-entrepreneurs-tomorrow/|title=New Entrepreneurs Foundation on hunt for 'young entrepreneurs of tomorrow' - Startups.co.uk: Starting a business advice and business ideas|publisher=|accessdate=31 July 2016}}</ref>
* Learning and Development Workshops - training workshops provided in partnership with business schools, including [[University College London|UCL]], [[London Business School]] and other specialist training providers. Workshops cover topics such as [[Negotiation]], [[Web development|Web Development]] and [[Sales pitch|Pitching]].
* Speaker Series - Past speakers include [[Dido Harding]] (CEO, [[TalkTalk Group|Talk Talk]]), Gerry Murphy,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.blackstone.com/the-firm/our-people/person?person=1000602|title=Gerry Murphy|website=www.blackstone.com|access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref> (Chairman, [[The Blackstone Group|Blackstone]]), [[Hermann Hauser|Dr. Hermann Hauser CBE]] (co-founder, [[Amadeus Capital Partners]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.amadeuscapital.com/|title=Home page - Amadeus Capital|website=Amadeus Capital|language=en-GB|access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref>), [[Lara Morgan]] (co-founder, [[Startup Britain|StartUp Britain]]), Brett Akker (founder, Streetcar, now [[Zipcar]]) and Marcia Kilgore (founder, Bliss, FitFlop & the Soap & Glory range<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://uk.linkedin.com/in/marcia-kilgore-15a3646|title=Marcia Kilgore {{!}} LinkedIn|website=uk.linkedin.com|access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref>)
* [[Coaching]] - an executive coach to help with personal development.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://newentrepreneursfoundation.com/programme-explained/coaches/|title=Coaches - New Entrepreneurs Foundation|language=en-US|access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref>
* [[Mentorship]] - a business mentor from a specific industry.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://newentrepreneursfoundation.com/programme-explained/mentors/|title=Business Mentors for Entrepreneurs|language=en-US|access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref>
Each June the current cohort and alumni pitch their business ventures to a panel of investors.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://us2.campaign-archive2.com/?u=a848bbe94ddea0cc8e6d81ea0&id=81f1eabca0&e=%255BUNIQID%255D|title=NEF Celebrates 5 Years of Developing Entrepreneurs|website=us2.campaign-archive2.com|access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref>
==Business== As of July 2016, NEF has developed 155 entrepreneurial ventures, of which 62 remain active, with more than £10m in investment raised and 650 jobs created.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://newentrepreneursfoundation.com/about-us-our-vision/what-we-have-achieved/|title=What we have achieved - New Entrepreneurs Foundation|language=en-US|access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref>
Among these businesses<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://newentrepreneursfoundation.com/meet-class-of-2015/nef-ventures/|title=NEF Ventures - New Entrepreneurs Foundation|language=en-US|access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref> are Inkpact,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.inkpact.com|title=Personalised Communication {{!}} Inkpact.com {{!}} Improved Marketing|website=www.inkpact.com|access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref> Pollen8,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://pollen8.io/|title=pollen8 - Work done better together|website=pollen8.io|access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref> Plus44 Holdings (whose primary product is Sliide App),<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://sliideairtime.ng/|title=Sliide Airtime|website=sliideairtime.ng|access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref> Stand4Socks,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.stand4socks.com/|title=Stand4 Socks - Socks for Social Causes - StandOut Stand4!|website=Stand4Socks|access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref> Krzana,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.krzana.com/|title=Krzana - The Real-Time Search Engine|website=www.krzana.com|access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref> Wiser,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://wearewiser.com/|title=Wiser|website=wearewiser.com|access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref> Sideways6,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sideways6.com|title=Sideways 6 – Crowdsourcing Employee Ideas with Office 365 and Yammer|website=www.sideways6.com|access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref> Turn Partners<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.turnpartners.com|title=Turn Partners|website=www.turnpartners.com|access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref> and CharlieHR.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.charliehr.com/|title=Charlie – The free HR platform for startups|website=www.charliehr.com|access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref>

[[Malay titles|Dato']] '''Ong Beng Seng''' ({{zh|t=|s=王明星|p=Wáng Míng Xīng}} born January 1946) is a Singaporean [[billionaire]] businessman, and husband of [[Christina Ong]]. He is the founder of the Singapore-based organisation Hotel Properties, and a shareholder in many businesses. ''[[Forbes (magazine)|Forbes]]'' estimates the net worth of Ong and his wife at $1.8 billion (as of July 2014), making them the 15th richest people in Singapore.<ref>[https://www.forbes.com/profile/beng-seng-christina-ong-ong Forbes, "Singapore's 50 Richest: #15 Ong Beng Seng & Christina Ong"]</ref>
==Early life== Ong was born in January 1946,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://beta.companieshouse.gov.uk/officers/UAu09ERPsOGNkjEA6BrJHhqJy9M/appointments |title=Ong Beng Seng ONG - Personal Appointments (free information from Companies House) |publisher=Beta.companieshouse.gov.uk |date= |accessdate=13 May 2017}}</ref> in Malaysia. When he was four years old, his family relocated to Singapore. His career began when he joined an insurance firm for ships. In 1975, he joined [[Kuo International]], founded by businessman Peter Fu Yun Siak and there he met his later-to-be spouse, [[Christina Ong|Christina]].<ref name="Independent 1"/>
==Career== After beginning his trading career at Kuo International, Ong went on to found his own firm, [[Hotel Properties Limited]]. Today, he controls many businesses, including a few based in [[Bond Street]] in London, and his investments are worth tens of millions of dollars.<ref name="Independent 1"/> He is a well-established hotelier, having bought and built many hotels worldwide.<ref name="Independent 1"/> Ong is credited as one among the few who brought the [[Singapore Grand Prix]] to the country, the first [[Formula One]] night race.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.formula1.com/races/in_detail/singapore_854/circuit_history.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-06-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120124034034/http://www.formula1.com/races/in_detail/singapore_854/circuit_history.html |archivedate=24 January 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
==Personal life== A "glitzy figure in Singapore and abroad",<ref name="Independent 1"/> Ong is married to [[Christina Ong]] (née Fu), the daughter of a businessman. They have two children, a daughter and a son.<ref name="Independent 1"/> Ong was described by Hilary Clarke of ''[[The Independent]]'' as "media shy" and "notoriously secretive".<ref name="Independent 1">{{cite news|newspaper=[[The Independent]] |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/profile-beng-seng-and-christina-ong-asian-pair-sell-west-buy-east-1153092.html |title=Profile: Beng Seng and Christina Ong: Asian pair sell west, buy east |date=29 March 1998 |first=Hilary |last=Clarke }}</ref> Despite that, he is known to be well-acquainted with many Hollywood celebrities.<ref name="Independent 1"/>
==Wealth== Ong's business approach is to "[b]uy when rents and properties are cheap and sell when they are not."<ref name="Independent 1"/> As of July 2012, the Ong family, comprising Ong and his wife, is worth $1.6 [[list of billionaires|billion]], based on estimates by Forbes, making the couple Singapore's 10th richest persons.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/beng-seng-ong/ |title=Ong Beng Seng & Christina Ong |publisher=[[Forbes]] |accessdate=4 June 2013 }}</ref>

[[File:Osama Daoud Abdellatif.jpg|thumb|Osama Daoud]] '''Osama D. Abdel Latif''' is a tycoon [[Sudan|Sudanese]] businessman and the chairman of [[DAL Group]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://abcnews.go.com/WN/story?id=3184599&page=1|title=China Interest Helps Sudan, Hurts Darfur|last=News|first=A. B. C.|date=2009-02-09|website=ABC News|language=en|access-date=2018-07-09}}</ref>
==Business==
===Dal Group=== Osama is the chairman of [DAL Group], based in [[Khartoum]], [[Sudan]].<ref>Latif, Osama D. "Chairman's Message." DAL Group- Chairman's Message. DAL Group. Web. 11 Nov. 2010. <http://www.dalgroup.com/dg/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=31&Itemid=50>.</ref> The Dal Group invests in diverse and various fields via a collection of companies including Dal Motors, Dal Engineering, Dal Food (which includes Sayga flour, the Blue Nile Dairy, Nobo Pasta, exclusive bottler of Coca-Cola in Sudan), Dal Agriculture, Sutrac and Sudanese Liquid Air. as well as many other companies. The Dal Group has also founded the Khartoum International Community School and become the official dealers of JVC Electronics in Sudan.
Inheriting an engineering & tractor company from his father, he rapidly expanded it to its modern-day stature as Sudan’s largest conglomerate.<ref name=“veconomist” >{{cite news|author=|title=Sudan’s economy is in trouble, even without sanctions|url=https://www.economist.com/news/middle-east-and-africa/21730152-america-has-lifted-trade-embargo-rapid-growth-will-not-be-easy|work=[[The Economist]]|date=14 October 2017}}</ref>
==Personal life== He is married and has 6 children.

'''PerForm''' and '''PerForm PRO''' were electronic form programs, initially designed to work under [[Graphics Environment Manager|GEM]] in [[DOS]]. Later versions were designed to work in [[Windows 3.1]], at which point it was succeeded by [[FormFlow]].
The initial version of PerForm was created in 1988 and was the first product released by [[Canada|Canadian]] software firm [[Delrina]], which became best known for its later fax software program, [[WinFax]]. Chief Technical Officer [[Bert Amato]] and President of the company [[Mark Skapinker]] came up with the idea for the product while working as consultants that what their clients wanted was a way to fill in forms electronically, rather than an easier way to create paper-based forms from a computer.<ref name="Softwarriors p34">{{Cite journal | last = Walmsley | first = Ann | title = Attack of the Softwarriors | journal = Report on Business Magazine | page = 34 | date = March 1994 }}</ref> The program consisted of two parts: a form design module which gave users a graphical user interface for creating and arranging form elements, using tools largely familiar to those using desktop publishing or paint programs of the era, and a separate form filling program which would display the resulting form that the user could then fill in<ref name="Zisman">{{cite web |url= http://www.zisman.ca/Articles/1991-92/Input_May92.html |title= PerForm Pro |last= Zisman |first= Alan |date= May 1992 |website= Alan Zisman on Technology |publisher= INPUT |access-date= November 15, 2017}}</ref>. Those entering information into the forms could not change or alter the forms; they were limited to adding information in the various form fields on screen. Some of the potential uses of the program included being able to create invoices, payment records, personnel and payroll forms, and just about any other standardized form that may have been required.<ref name="Zisman">{{cite web |url= http://www.zisman.ca/Articles/1991-92/Input_May92.html |title= PerForm Pro |last= Zisman |first= Alan |date= May 1992 |website= Alan Zisman on Technology |publisher= INPUT |access-date= November 15, 2017}}</ref> Later versions of the program had some integration with Delrina's popular [[WinFax]] program, enabling users to [[fax]] material to clients based on information entered into PerForm.<ref name="Heck">{{cite web |url= https://books.google.ca/books?id=zDoEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA104 |title= PerForm, BizForms templates make filling in, filing forms a breeze |last= Heck |first= Mike |date= May 1995 |website= Google Books |publisher= InfoWorld |access-date= November 15, 2017}}</ref>
There was significant and long-term uptake of electronic forms products within governmental agencies both in Canada<ref name="TransportCanada">{{cite web|url=http://www.tc.gc.ca/gol/environment.htm |title="TRANSPORT CANADA'S IM/IT ENVIRONMENT 2006/2007", with a contemporary reference to the use of Delrina FormFlow |accessdate=2007-09-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070902012852/http://www.tc.gc.ca/gol/environment.htm |archivedate=2007-09-02 |df= }}</ref> and the United States,<ref name="USOffice">{{cite web | title = Office of Personnel Management Electronic Forms, FormFlow Versions of Standard Forms, July 14, 2000 | url= http://www.opm.gov/forms/html/ff_sf.htm | accessdate = August 24, 2009 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070331223006/http://www.opm.gov/forms/html/ff_sf.htm |archivedate = March 31, 2007}}</ref> the latter spurred on in particular by the requirements of the [[Paperwork Reduction Act]] to reduce the total amount of paperwork handled by the United States government.<ref name="Asbrand">{{Cite journal | last = Asbrand | first = Deborah | title = Forms automation needs brains | journal = InfoWorld | page = 79 | date = October 10, 1994 }}</ref> One of the firm's early major software deals included a multi-year agreement to sell PerForm to the U.S. Navy in 1990.<ref name="Softwarriors p34"/> Soon after the software was installed on [[Compaq]] [[laptops]] that accompanied U.S. troops during the [[First Gulf War]], where it was used to requisition "everything from [[Coca-Cola]] to [[Outhouse|privies]]".<ref name="Softwarriors p34"/> Other significant volume sales went to [[3M]] and [[Rockwell International]].<ref name="Softwarriors p34"/> What helped set apart Delrina's electronic forms from its competitors in product reviews included its easy-to-use interface, its extensive development tools, and its comparatively low price.<ref name="FormTest">{{Cite journal | title = Putting electronic forms to the test | journal = InfoWorld | pages = 93–105 | date = May 2, 1994 }}</ref> It also scored highly when it came to workflow and routing functions as well as security features.<ref name="Melnitsky">{{Cite journal | last = Melnitsky | first = Stuart | title = Form is function | journal = Network World | page = 48 | date = December 2, 1996 }}</ref> In early 1991 [[InfoWorld]] selected PerForm Pro as its "Product of the Year" in the electronic forms category, and [[PC World Magazine]] gave the product it's "Best Buy" designation.<ref name="ProductOfTheYear1990">{{cite press release | title = Delrina's PerFORM Chosen Product of the Year | publisher = Delrina Technology Inc. | date = February 18, 1991 }}</ref> PerForm proved to be successful in its niche, effectively capturing the retail market by 1993.<ref name="Kevin Strehlo p.88">{{Cite journal | last = Strehlo | first = Kevin | title = FormFlow has the smarts to truly automate form routing | journal = Network World | page = 88 | date = July 12, 1993 }}</ref>
The electronic forms division of Delrina was sold to [[JetForm]] in 1996. JetForm in turn was bought by [[Adobe Systems|Adobe]], and the electronic forms products were officially discontinued in 2004.

{{ infobox person | name = Philippe Camus | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1948|06|28|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Paris]], [[France]] | nationality = [[France|French]] | education = [[École Normale Supérieure]]
[[Sciences Po]] | occupation = Chairman of the Board of [[Alcatel-Lucent]] }} '''Philippe Camus''' (born 28 June 1948) is a [[France|French]] businessman.[https://www.forbes.com/profile/philippe-camus/70376 Forbes] He serves as the non-executive [[Chairman of the Board]] of [[Alcatel-Lucent]]. ==Biography== Camus was born on June 28, 1948. He is a graduate of [[Sciences Po]] and the [[École Normale Supérieure]].[http://www.evercore.com/userdetail/index.php?userid=1245 Evercome Partners] In 1972, he started working for the [[Caisse des dépôts et consignations]].[http://www.alcatel-lucent.com/pressdocs/20080902-PC-Bio-E.pdf Alcatel-Lucent] In 1992, he joined the [[Lagardère Group]] and served as Chairman of the Supervisory Board of [[Banque Arjil]] until 1993. In 1993, he was appointed as Managing Director of the Lagardère Group and helped restructure the [[Matra|Matra Group]]. He also helped create [[EADS]], and was its CEO from 2000 to 2005. In 2008, he was appointed as Chairman of the Board of Alcatel-Lucent.[http://www.alcatel-lucent.com/wps/portal/!ut/p/kcxml/04_Sj9SPykssy0xPLMnMz0vM0Y_QjzKLd4x3tXDUL8h2VAQAURh_Yw!!?LMSG_CABINET=Docs_and_Resource_Ctr&LMSG_CONTENT_FILE=News_Releases_2008/News_Article_001199.xml Alcatel Lucent appointment] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160401031237/http://www3.alcatel-lucent.com/wps/portal/!ut/p/kcxml/04_Sj9SPykssy0xPLMnMz0vM0Y_QjzKLd4x3tXDUL8h2VAQAURh_Yw!!?LMSG_CABINET=Docs_and_Resource_Ctr&LMSG_CONTENT_FILE=News_Releases_2008%2FNews_Article_001199.xml |date=2016-04-01 }} From 1996 to 2001, he served on the [[Autorité des marchés financiers (France)|French supervisory authority for the financial markets]]. From 2001 to 2005, he was the President of [[GIFAS]]. He now serves as co-managing partner of the [[Lagardère Group]] and Senior Managing Director of [[investment bank]] [[Evercore Partners]]. He also serves on the boards of directors of [[Crédit Agricole]], [[Accor]], and [[Schlumberger]]. He is also a member of the [[Paris Europlace Association]].[http://www.paris-europlace.net/ Paris Europlace] He was decorated the Cross of the [[Federal Cross of Merit|German Merit Order]] in 2004 and the Officer of the French [[Légion d’Honneur]] in 2005. ==References== {{reflist}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Camus, Philippe}} [[Category:1948 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:French businesspeople]] [[Category:École Normale Supérieure alumni]] [[Category:Sciences Po alumni]] [[Category:Officiers of the Légion d'honneur]] [[Category:Officers Crosses of the Order of Merit of the Federal Republic of Germany]] [[Category:Crédit Agricole]] [[Category:Schlumberger]]

{{Infobox International Labour Organization convention |code= C173 |name= Protection of Workers' |force= June 8, 1995 |classify= Protection of Wages |subject= Wages |prev= [[Working Conditions (Hotels and Restaurants) Convention, 1991]] |next= [[Prevention of Major Industrial Accidents Convention, 1993]] |shelved= }} '''Protection of Workers' Claims (Employer's Insolvency) Convention, 1992''' is an [[International Labour Organization]] [[International Labour Organization#International Labour Conference|Convention]]. It was established in 1992, with the preamble stating:
Stressing the importance of the protection of workers' claims in the event of the insolvency of their employer and recalling the provisions on this subject in Article 11 of the Protection of Wages Convention, 1949, and Article 11 of the Workmen's Compensation (Accidents) Convention, 1925,...
== Modification == The convention revised the principles contained in ILO Convention C95, [[Protection of Wages Convention, 1949]]. == Ratifications== As of 2013, the convention has been ratified by 21 states. == External links == *[http://www.ilo.org/dyn/normlex/en/f?p=NORMLEXPUB:12100:0::NO:12100:P12100_INSTRUMENT_ID:312318:NO Text]. *[http://www.ilo.org/dyn/normlex/en/f?p=1000:11300:0::NO:11300:P11300_INSTRUMENT_ID:312318 Ratifications]. {{more citations needed|date=August 2015}} {{Use mdy dates|date=May 2015}} {{Infobox video game | title = Railroad Tycoon II | image = Railroad Tycoon 2 cover.jpg | caption = | developer = [[PopTop Software]] | publisher = {{vgr|NA|[[Gathering of Developers]]|EU|[[Take-Two Interactive]]}} | designer = Phil Steinmeyer | programmer = Phil Steinmeyer | composer = Jim Callahan | series = [[Railroad Tycoon (series)|''Railroad Tycoon'']] | platforms = [[Microsoft Windows]], [[Linux]], [[Mac OS]], [[Dreamcast]], [[PlayStation (console)|PlayStation]] | released = '''Windows'''{{vgrelease|NA|October 31, 1998|EU|1998}}'''PlayStation'''{{vgrelease|NA|January 31, 2000|EU|2000}}'''Dreamcast'''{{vgrelease|NA|June 30, 2000|EU|June 30, 2000}} | genre = [[Business simulation game|Business simulation]] | modes = [[Single-player]], [[Multiplayer video game|multiplayer]] }}
'''''Railroad Tycoon II''''' is a [[train simulator|train]] and [[business simulation]] video game for [[Microsoft Windows]], [[Mac OS]], [[PlayStation (console)|PlayStation]] and [[Dreamcast]] in the [[Railroad Tycoon (series)|''Railroad Tycoon'' series]]. The Dreamcast version is a Gold Edition with improved graphics and gameplay. ''Railroad Tycoon II: Gold Edition'' was ported to [[Linux]] by [[Loki Software]].
Gameplay is displayed in [[dimetric projection|dimetric view]], unlike the top-down view of ''[[Railroad Tycoon]]''.
==Gameplay== [[Image:Railroadtyccon screenshot.jpg|thumb|left|Screenshot from ''Railroad Tycoon II''.]] ''Railroad Tycoon II'' is a [[railroad simulation]] that covers the entire history of railroads from inception to the present day and beyond. The player chooses a map and assumes the role of chairman of a [[railroad company]]. The player tries to make profits for investors and completes various other objectives while being hindered by rivals, random events such as train breakdowns, [[train robber]]s, economic swings, and scripted events particular to the scenario.
Most of the gameplay consists of building tracks, stations and trains, which are used for hauling passengers and freight from one station to another. Delivery revenue can vary by time, distance, demand, cargo type, economic state, station improvements and difficulty level. Companies can connect to and use each other's track and stations, so revenue can be split. Expenses include the fuel, track and engine maintenance and management fee. The fuel cost depends on the cargo weight and the distance each engine runs. Engine maintenance depends on engine age and the engine's type (some locomotives cost more to maintain than others). The elder engines cost more to keep them on the line. The track maintenance is solely calculated from track [[Distance|mileage]].
The player will determine what kind of cargo(es) to put on/off at each station that the player adds to its routing. Way-points may also be inserted to override default track selection where multiple paths are possible.
There are many industries in the game, and each can produce and/or convert specific cargoes. For example, coal mines produce coal, iron mines produce iron, and, in the advanced game, a [[steel mill]] can convert 1 load of [[iron]] plus 1 load of [[coal]] into 2 loads of [[steel]]. The players are encouraged to find a chain of production to make new cargo by hauling the right type of cargo to each step of the industries. By doing this right, the player can haul raw materials one way, "create" manufactured return cargo, and make even more money hauling finished products back the other way.
===Locomotives and industry=== One of the key elements of game play relates to the player purchasing and operating a variety of locomotives, each of which possesses different attributes relating to speed, fuel type, preferred cargo, and the ability to traverse hills and steep track grades. In general, the player should balance the cost of operating a train and the time required to transport cargo, with the balance being that the profit from cargo delivery outweighs train operating costs. The player also may purchase various industrial plants to earn extra money based on amount of cargo received and delivered. Basic industry, such as [[bakery|bakeries]], [[Textile manufacturing|textile mill]]s, and [[Tool and die maker|tool and die factories]], earns less profit than advanced factories such as [[Canning|canneries]], steel mills and [[car|automobile]] plants, although the latter require multiple goods delivered to produce one final product. Furthermore, idle industries which do not produce goods will generate a negative profit, thus increasing overall operating costs and [[Overhead (business)|overhead]].
The following locomotives are available for game play. Locomotives are only seen in specific time periods and scenarios. In addition to the attributes described above, locomotives are subject to "mechanical reliability", which is a randomly generated factor influencing how often a locomotive will break down. All locomotives begin their operational lives with a set chance of mechanical failure, with some types more prone to breakdowns than others. Breakdown percentage chance increases the older a locomotive becomes. A train may also suffer a [[train wreck|wreck]], which completely destroys the locomotive and all hauled cargo. {{columns-list|colwidth=15em| * [[Richard Trevithick|Trevithick]] (1804) * [[John Bull (locomotive)|John Bull]] (1831) * [[DeWitt Clinton (locomotive)|DeWitt Clinton]] (1833) * [[Prussian P 2|Prussian]] (1837) * [[4-4-0#American development|American C]] (1848) * [[GWR 3031 Class|Iron Duke]] (1855) * [[4-4-0|8 Wheeler]] (1868) * [[South Devon Railway Buffalo class|Vulcan]] (1872) * [[2-8-0|Consolidation]] (1877) * [[Shay locomotive|Truck Shay]] (1882) * [[Mastodon (steam locomotive)|Mastodon]] (1890) * [[4-6-0|10 Wheeler]] (1892) * [[GER Class 527|Mogul]] (1895) * [[:File:B-and-O electric.jpg|Bo-Bo]] (1895) * [[Alfred de Glehn|Atlantic]] (1902) * [[Camelback locomotive|Camelback]] (1905) * [[4-6-2|Pacific]] (1908) * [[Prussian G 10|Class G10]] (1910) * [[2-6-2|Prairie]] (1912) * [[PRR D16|D16sb American]] (1914) * [[Saxon XIII H|Class 13 H]] (1917) * [[USRA 0-6-0]] (1918) * [[2-8-2|Mikado]] (1919) * [[SBB-CFF-FFS Be 4/6 12303-12342|Be 4/6 II]] (1920) * [[GER Class S69|Class B12]] (1923) * [[ÖBB Class 1045|Class 1045]] (1927) * [[USRA 0-8-0]] (1930) * [[LNER Class A4 4468 Mallard|Class A4 Mallard]] (1935) * [[PRR GG1|GG1]] (1935) * [[DRG Class E 18|Class E18]] (1936) * [[NYC Hudson|Hudson]] (1937) * [[Southern Pacific 4449|Daylight]] * J3A Streamliner (1938) * [[SBB-CFF-FFS Ae 8/14|Landi-Lok]] (1939) * [[DRG Class E 94|Class 1020]] (1941) * [[Union Pacific Big Boy|Big Boy]] * [[PRR T1|4-4-4-4 T1]] (1945) * [[EMD F3|F3]] * [[ALCO PA|PA-1]] (1946) * [[EMD F9|F9]] (1949) * [[EMD GP9|GP9]] (1954) * E69 (1955) * [[TGV|TGVx Bullet Train]] (1957) * [[EMD GP18|GP18]] (1958) * [[DB Class V 200|V200]] (1959) * [[PRR E44|Penn E44]] (1960) * [[British Rail Class 55|Class 55 Deltic]] (1961) * [[Shinkansen|Shinkansen Bullet]] (1966) * [[EMD FP45|FP45]] (1968) * [[EMD SD45|SD45]](1972) * [[EMD SDP40|SDP40]] (1973) * [[GE E60|E60CP]] * TGV Bullet Train * [[DB Class 111|Class E111]] (1974) * [[FS Class E.656|E656 Camino-FS]] (1975) * [[GE Dash 9-44CW|Dash 9]] (1993) * [[GE Genesis|AMD-103]] * [[Thalys|Thalys Bullet Train]] (1994) * [[Eurostar|Eurostar Bullet Train]] * [[DR Class 130 family|Class 232]] (1997) * [[DR 18 201]] (1998) * [[FS Class E.412|E-412 Brenner]] (1999) }} The game also features one futuristic train, the "Mag-Lev TBX-1" which is portrayed as released in the (then) future date of 2008. The train operates using [[Maglev]] technology which, as of 2015, has been prototyped in both Europe and Japan. The first successful Maglev train to be operated was the [[SCMaglev]] with speeds approaching 400 miles per hour.
===Economics===
Gameplay also includes financial manipulation of companies, issuing [[bond (finance)|bond]]s, [[share repurchase]]s, [[stock issue]]s, manipulating [[dividend]]s, merging with other companies and declaring [[bankruptcy]]. These features are required in some scenarios and may be used for either great financial gain or total fiscal disaster.
In normal financial mode, the player may buy or sell any companies' stocks at various prices depending upon the economy. On advanced settings, the broker may allow the player to [[margin (finance)#Margin buying|buy on margin]] or [[short (finance)|short sell]] stocks if he has enough value of stocks or cash to rely on. The computer players may also engage in these practices and will attempt to bankrupt the player when he is heavily in debt.
The economy may fluctuate during gameplay, with five economic states possible: Booming, Prosperity, Normal, [[Recession]] and [[Depression (economics)|Depression]]. When the economy is good, the revenue of hauled goods and stock prices will be higher. Bond interest rates will also be adjusted with the economy level, including the interest received from cash and the interest paid for the bonds.
===Campaigns and scenarios===
The original game features eighteen missions, divided between North America, Europe and the rest of the world. The missions can be played on three difficulty levels, and each also includes three listed objectives. Completing only the first objective awards the player a bronze medal, the first two a silver medal, and all three a gold medal. The player may play any mission in each set as many times as they wish; they may also continue even though a mission has been failed. The final score for the whole 18 mission campaign is calculated by the difficulty level and the number of each type of medal achieved.
In addition to the campaign, ''Railroad Tycoon II'' features many single scenarios. As with the campaign, each scenario is based on a geographical location, which may be fictional. Most scenarios also have a medal system similar to that of the campaign, although any scenario may be played in [[sandbox mode]] as well. Many scenarios constrain the player to some specific point on the timeline and feature scripted events: for example, the [[Korea]]n map presents an [[alternate history|alternative history]] as the player is informed about the averted [[Korean civil war]].
Additional single scenarios may be created using the [[map editor]] included. Maps may be imported, drawn from scratch, or edited from existing maps and saved under new names. Many fan creations have been shared on various [[fan site]]s.
==Development== In late 1997, [[Bruce Shelley]] said of his chance of developing ''Railroad Tycoon II'', "I would be happy to work on such a game but there are real doubts about its ability to generate sufficient sales in this blockbuster market where a few of the games make most of the money."<ref>https://web.archive.org/web/19990506043125/http://www.gamecenter.com:80/News/Item/Cont/0,4,0-1280_2,00.html</ref>
===Soundtrack=== The soundtrack of ''Railroad Tycoon II'' consist mostly of classical "railroad" blues and bluegrass genre from the era the game revolves around. These pieces were not, unlike most contemporary games, midi files, but rather high quality studio recordings; some even with vocals. This fact has contributed to the solid ratings this game has received.<!--The soundtrack consists of the following tracks:-->
===Editions=== ''Railroad Tycoon 2: Gold'' is a collection of ''Railroad Tycoon 2'' and ''Railroad Tycoon 2: The Second Century'', in one package. ''Railroad Tycoon 2: Platinum'' is equivalent to the ''Gold Edition'' plus over 50 community-made maps added and enhanced mouse-wheel support. Maps (scenarios) developed specifically for the platinum edition may not function in some earlier versions. The last official [[patch (computing)|patch]] to ''Railroad Tycoon 2'' was [https://web.archive.org/web/20130414213020/http://www.shacknews.com/file/2301/railroad-tycoon-2-platinum-156-patch platinum v1.56] on February 19, 2003.<ref>{{Cite web|title = PhilSteinmeyer.com » Blog Archive » The missing Railroad Tycoon 2 map…|url = http://www.philsteinmeyer.com/55/the-missing-railroad-tycoon-2-map/|website = www.philsteinmeyer.com|access-date = 2016-01-11}}</ref>
==Reception== ===Sales=== ''Railroad Tycoon II'' was a commercial success.<ref name=wired /> Its sales surpassed 500,000 copies globally by February 1999,<ref name=expansion>{{cite web |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050207040945/http://cdmag.com/articles/017/193/rr2_ep.html |url=http://cdmag.com:80/articles/017/193/rr2_ep.html |title=''Railroad Tycoon II: The Second Century'' Expansion Pack Announced |author=Fudge, James |date=February 19, 1999 |work=[[Computer Games Magazine|Computer Games Strategy Plus]] |archivedate=February 7, 2005 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> and its computer version alone sold more than 1.5 million copies by August 2001.<ref name=wired>{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170930192333/https://www.wired.com/2001/08/game-over-for-max-payne-makers/ |url=https://www.wired.com/2001/08/game-over-for-max-payne-makers/ |title=Game Over for ''Max Payne'' Makers | author=Shachtman, Noah | date=August 16, 2001 |work=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]] |archivedate=September 30, 2017 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> In the United States, the game and its ''Gold'' edition together sold 351,000 copies by October 2001.<ref name=godsales /> According to Franz J. Felsl of PopTop, much of ''Railroad Tycoon II''{{'}}s success came from European markets; he explained that it "did better in Europe than it did in the US, which is not the way things usually end up."<ref name=eurogamer>{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170930200603/http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/i_franzf |url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/i_franzf |title=Franz J Felsl of PopTop | author=Bye, John | date=June 23, 2000 |work=[[Eurogamer]] |archivedate=September 30, 2017 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
By August 2000, ''Railroad Tycoon II'' had been released in 39 unique [[Stock keeping unit|SKU]]s worldwide, including eight Windows versions in English alone. PopTop's Phil Steinmeyer wrote that roughly 33% of the game's sales derived from the ''Gold'' edition and ''Second Century'' expansion, and that the port for Macintosh "sold respectably", while the PlayStation version was unsuccessful. He accredited the game's number of versions with its commercial success, and wrote in August 2000, "Overall, had we only released the original game, in English, for Windows only, our sales would be less than a quarter of what they are now."<ref name=steinmeyersales>{{cite web |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050317062552/http://www.cdmag.com/articles/029/034/isf_column.html |url=http://www.cdmag.com:80/articles/029/034/isf_column.html |title=Inside the Sausage Factory; Language Barriers |author=Steinmeyer, Phil |date=August 14, 2000 |work=[[Computer Games Magazine]] |archivedate=March 17, 2005 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> In 2003, Steinmeyer remarked that ''Railroad Tycoon II'' continued to sell "pretty well".<ref name=cgmprev>{{cite journal |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100303225823/http://www.cgonline.com/computer-games-magazine/article/return_of_the_king1/ |url=http://www.cgonline.com/computer-games-magazine/article/return_of_the_king1/ |title=Return of the King |author=Sones, Benjamin E. | issue=150 | date=May 2003 |work=[[Computer Games Magazine]] |archivedate=March 3, 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>

===Awards=== ''Railroad Tycoon II'' won ''[[Computer Games Magazine|Computer Games Strategy Plus]]''{{'}}s and [[CNET|CNET Gamecenter]]'s 1998 "Strategy Game of the Year" awards; the former magazine's editors wrote that it "capture[d] almost all of the things gamers had come to love about the original."<ref name=gamecenter1998>{{cite web | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20001216230700/http://www.gamecenter.com:80/Features/Exclusives/Awards98/index.html | url=http://www.gamecenter.com:80/Features/Exclusives/Awards98/index.html | title=The CNET Gamecenter.com Awards for 1998 | author=The Gamecenter Editors | date=January 29, 1999 | work=[[CNET|CNET Gamecenter]] | archivedate=January 21, 2000 | deadurl=yes }}</ref><ref name=cgmawards1998>{{cite web |author=Staff |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050203235412/http://cdmag.com/articles/017/163/best_of_year.html |url=http://cdmag.com:80/articles/017/163/best_of_year.html |title=The Best of 1998 |date=February 11, 1999 |work=[[Computer Games Magazine|Computer Games Strategy Plus]] |archivedate=February 3, 2005 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> It also received [[IGN]]'s "Best Soundtrack" award.<ref name=ignawards1998>{{cite web |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20020404002022/http://pc.ign.com/articles/066/066665p1.html |url=http://pc.ign.com:80/articles/066/066665p1.html |title=IGNPC's Best of 1998 Awards |author=IGN Staff |work=[[IGN]] |archivedate=April 4, 2002 |date=January 29, 1999 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
The game was a finalist for ''[[Computer Gaming World]]''{{'}}s 1998 "Best Strategy", [[GameSpot]]'s "Strategy Game of the Year", IGN's "Best Strategy Game of the Year" and ''[[PC Gamer US]]''{{'}}s "The Best Real-Time Strategy Game" awards, all of which ultimately went to ''[[StarCraft]]''.<ref name=ignawards1998 /><ref name=cgwpremier1998>{{cite journal | author=Staff | journal=[[Computer Gaming World]] | title=''Computer Gaming World''{{'}}s 1999 Premier Awards; ''CGW'' Presents the Best Games of 1998 |date=April 1999 | issue=177 | pages=90, 93, 96–105 }}</ref><ref name=pcgamerusawards1998>{{cite journal |date=March 1999 | title=The Fifth Annual ''PC Gamer'' Awards | volume=6 | number=3 | pages=64, 67, 70–73, 76–78, 84, 86, 87 | journal=[[PC Gamer US]] | author=Staff }}</ref><ref name=gamespot1998>{{cite web |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20000815235823/http://www.gamespot.com/features/awards1998/index.html |url=http://www.gamespot.com:80/features/awards1998/index.html |title=GameSpot's Best and Worst of 1998 |author=Staff |work=[[GameSpot]] |archivedate=August 15, 2000 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> ''Computer Gaming World''{{'}}s editors lauded ''Railroad Tycoon II'' as "a brilliant update of a gaming classic",<ref name=cgwpremier1998 /> and the staff of ''PC Gamer US'' wrote that the game "did a terrific job of immersing the player in a richly detailed world of empire-building, commerce and micro-management."<ref name=pcgamerusawards1998 />

==Legacy== ''Railroad Tycoon II'' became the first game published by [[Gathering of Developers]] to sell 1 million copies,<ref name=gamasutrasales>{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080325035317/http://www.gamasutra.com/view/feature/2131/the_strange_history_of_gamecocks_.php?print=1 |url=http://www.gamasutra.com/view/feature/2131/the_strange_history_of_gamecocks_.php?print=1 |title=The Strange History Of Gamecock's Mike Wilson | author=Kim, Tom | date=November 14, 2007 |work=[[Gamasutra]] |archivedate=March 25, 2008 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> and [[Geoff Keighley]] of ''[[Computer Gaming World]]'' declared it one of the publisher's few "certified hits." In the United States, the publisher's combined lifetime sales reached 1.3 million copies by October 2001, including the sales of ''Railroad Tycoon II''.<ref name=godsales>{{cite journal |title=READ.ME; G.O.D.'s Fall from Grace | author=Keighley, Geoff |issue=207 |date=October 2001 |pages=30–32 |journal=[[Computer Gaming World]] }}</ref> Gathering of Developers president Mike Wilson believed that the game put his company on the map, at a time when others in the computer game industry doubted that an independent publisher could succeed.<ref name=gamasutrasales />
It was featured in G4 Icons' episode 12 Sid Meier as part of Sid's history with games and computers.

{{Infobox person | name = Raoul Warocqué | image = | alt = | caption = Portrait of Raoul Warocqué | birth_name = <!-- only use if different from name --> | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1870|02|04}} | birth_place = [[Brussels]], [[Belgium]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|1917|05|28|1870|02|04}} | death_place = [[Brussels]], [[Belgium]] | nationality = Belgian | other_names = | occupation = Industrialist, politician, philanthropist | known_for = Founding the [[Musée royal de Mariemont]] }} '''Raoul Warocqué''' ([[Brussels]], 4 February 1870 – [[Brussels]], 28 May 1917), was a [[Belgium|Belgian]] industrialist from [[Wallonia]].
==Biography== Raoul was the great-grandson of [[Nicolas Warocqué]], the founder of the prominent Warocqué family. His father was [[Arthur Warocqué]], (1835–80),<ref>[https://archive.is/20120907064944/http://www.morlanwelz.be/histoire/vandeneynde/arthur_warocque.htm Arthur Warocqué (French)]</ref> a promotor of Belgian horticulture, after whom the [[Araceae|arum]] ''[[Anthurium warocqueanum]]'' was named.<ref>{{cite book | author=[[James Herbert Veitch]]| title=Hortus Veitchii| publisher=[[Caradoc Doy]] | year=2006|edition=reprint|pages=227| isbn=0-9553515-0-2}}</ref>
Warocqué was a [[philanthropist]] and a believer in [[paternalism]]. He was a [[freemason]] of the [[Grand Orient of Belgium]], Belgian [[patriotism|patriot]] and a [[monarchist|royalist]]. At the [[Universite Libre de Bruxelles]] (ULB), he participated in the ''Jeune Garde libérale'' (Young Liberal Guard).
[[File:Université de Mons-Hainaut (1).JPG|thumb|Building of the former ''École de Commerce'' in [[Mons]] which Warocqué founded]] Raoul Warocqué made the coal mines of [[Morlanwelz|Mariemont]] successful, and at 21 years of age had established a considerable fortune. A careful investment policy made him the richest man in Belgium at the beginning of the 20th century. His industrial ventures were numerous, such as in the coal mines of [[Campine]] as well as in other industrial sectors including [[Clabecq]], Gas and Electricity of Hainaut, railroads and coal mines in [[China]], tobacco in [[Portugal]], and others.
As a politician he was mayor of [[Morlanwelz]] and liberal deputy of [[Thuin]]. In [[Mariemont, Belgium|Mariemont]] and in [[Hainaut (province)|Hainaut]], he founded liberal organizations. He supported bills favorable to the [[working class]], while at the same time he was opposed to the right to strike. His most noted interventions relate to the [[Belgian Congo]], military service, compulsory education and coal mining.
As a philanthropist, he created open dormitories in Brussels (1891) which distributed soup and bread to the poor. He supported the ULB, the ''Ecole des Mines'' (School of Mining), and founded the ''Institut commercial'' (Commercial Institute) in [[Mons]] as well as the ''Athénée du Centre'' (Central Athenaeum) in [[Morlanwelz]], an orphanage, a childcare facility, a maternity hospital, and some other institutions.
He was also one of the financiers of the [[List of world expositions|World Fair of Brussels]] ([[Brussels International (1897)|1897]] and 1910) and of [[Charleroi]] (1911). He fell ill and died during [[World War I]], in 1917. On his death in 1917, his art and antiquities collections were donated to the Belgian state and now form the basis for the [[Musée royal de Mariemont]].
